lines.text: How dare you think such cheap tactics would work with me!
That ain't tactics, honey. It's just the beast in me.
I asked for nothing, I expected nothing and I got nothing.
What'd you expect for nothing?

[to the mail clerks]
Hurry up, fellas. I gotta count my fan mail.

[starts reading the envelopes]
Vince Everett. Everett. Everett.

[calls the mail clerks over]
Hey, you birds, come here. How would you like to make 5 cartons a piece?
Five? Who do you want us to murder?

This is the easiest money you'll ever make as long as you live. All's you gotta do is to keep your mouth shut. I mean, about the mail. I made a mistake and I gave the kid the best spot in the show. Naturally, if any word of this gets out all this mail's for Vince Everett, it makes me look bad. Follow? I mean me, the professional singer.
I, uh... I see.
If within a week the words not around, you get the cigarettes.
Yeah, but it's Everett's mail. Who's gonna keep him quiet?
If I know the warden, Everett will never get it.
I think I'm going to just hate you!
No, you ain't gonna hate me. I ain't gonna let you hate me.

[their first meeting, after she has criticized his dull singing style]
Okay, you're used to the top talent. What are you wasting your time working *me* over for?

[softly]
I like the way you swing a guitar.
[they look at each other and start laughing]
Yeah, I guess I *did* get a lot of wrist action into it, didn't I?
How's your headache?
I'm coming all unglued.
[they continue to kiss]
Listen, Sonny. You don't own that song. It's a published tune. Anyone can record it.
You turned it down. You said you didn't like it.
We simply didn't want to record it with an unknown.
What about my arrangement?
So see your lawyer. You can't copyright an arrangement.
You're a thievin' rat!
[goes after him]
Now you listen to me, sonny.

[grabs him]
Don't "sonny" me, you louse!
[slaps him a couple times and throws him back in his chair]
Crawl back under your rock, you snake!
Hey, what are you, man? Some kind of an animal?
"Do unto others as they would do unto you, only do it first."
Yeah. That's right. Do it first.
And it's just as bad on the outside. Worse. Remember that.
I don't aim to forget it.
Vince, what about Laurel Records? What is it?
We got an offer for the label, Peg. It's just too good to turn down.
An offer? What kind of an offer?
To sell out to Geneva Records.
[raises his hand]
Wait a minute. Wait'll you hear the deal. Seven hundred and fifty thousand dollars, a capital gain. That's 225,000 in cold cash for you, after taxes.
But, Vince, I don't wanna sell out.
I'm afraid you got not choice, kid. I own...
I know. Sixty percent.
That's the way the mop flops. You'd think I was tryin' to rob you. After all, you're getting practically a quarter of a million dollars.
Dollars? Dollars? Is that the beginning and the end of the world for you? Is there no emotion left in you but the lust for money?
Emotion? What emotion? It's strictly business between you and me. You said that.

I don't care what I said. We started this thing together. We nursed it and brought it up, you and I. It may just be a ledger page to you and Mr. Shores... but to me it's part of my life! Oh, go ahead and sell it! I don't care what you do!
[goes away crying]
Trampin' on me is one thing, sonny.
[takes off his jacket]
Hurtin' a little girl like Peggy is another.
Now just don't you get no ideas, Hunk.
There comes a time when you gotta take a hand in things, and that time is now.
Don't push me, Hunk.

[roles up his sleeves]
I'm gonna beat the hell outta you.
Don't try it. You're talkin' crazy, man.
You know you got it comin', son.
I said don't try...
[Hunk hits him]
I didn't see you applauding. You didn't like me?
You've come a long way since cellblock 21.
Yeah, and it's been a tough road to hoe.
Oh, I don't know. You haven't hardly touched the ground at all.
What do you mean by that crack?
You walked most of the way on other people.
Ah, you're just gettin' bitter, old buddy.
I'll send a woman up to make the bed directly.
Okay.

[sees him still standing there]
What do you want?
It's custom to tip a man he brings you to your room.
no tip.
Where's the nearest pawnshop?
Oh, down the street to the right, a couple of blocks.
What you gonna do? Buy yourself a diamond ring?
No. I'm gonna buy a guitar and sing love songs to you.
That's all the sympathy I'll give you. Pity's a commodity in here. You buy it and sell it just like anything else.
Laury is a real cool little singer. I'm takin' her to New York with me.
Oh! In that case, I don't think I'll go.
Were you planning to go? What for?
No reason I can think of now.
Got nothin' to do with the record business.
Of course not.
It's just like you said that night in Joplin, "You and me, it's strictly business."
Let's keep it that way.
Who's gonna see us here?
I got my eye on you every minute.
You know how to float?
No.
C'mon, I'll teach you.
